dt: {bc}to be or to stay at rest in a horizontal position {bc}be {d_link|prostrate|prostrate:1} {bc}{sx|rest||}, {sx|recline||}

dt.t: {wi}lie{/wi} motionless
{wi}lie{/wi} asleep
{wi}lie{/wi} in wait

dt: {bc}to be in a helpless or defenseless state

dt.t: the town {it}lay{/it} at the mercy of the invaders

dt: {bc}to be or remain in a flat or horizontal position upon a broad support

dt.t: books {it}lying{/it} on the table
the route {it}lay{/it} to the west

dt: {bc}to occupy a certain relative place or position

dt.t: hills {wi}lie{/wi} behind us

dt: {bc}to have a place in relation to something else

dt.t: the real reason {wi}lies{/wi} deeper

dt: {bc}to have an effect through {d_link|mere|mere:1} presence, weight, or relative position

dt.t: remorse {it}lay{/it} heavily on him
the choice {it}lay{/it} between fighting or surrendering
the success of the book {wi}lies{/wi} in its direct style
responsibility {it}lay{/it} with the adults

dt: {bc}to remain unused, unsought, or uncared for
{bc}to stay in hiding {bc}strive to avoid notice
{bc}to {d_link|bide|bide} one's time {bc}remain secretly ready for action

pt: {i_link|Lay|lay:1} has been used intransitively in the sense of "lie"

pt.t: going to {wi}lay{/wi} down for a quick nap

pt: since the 14th century. The practice was unremarked until around 1770; attempts to correct it have been a fixture of schoolbooks ever since. Generations of teachers and critics have succeeded in taming most literary and learned writing, but intransitive {it}lay{/it} persists in familiar speech and is a bit more common in general prose than one might suspect. Much of the problem lies in the confusing similarity of the principal parts of the two words. Another influence may be a folk belief that {it}lie{/it} is for people and {it}lay{/it} is for things. Some commentators are ready to abandon the distinction, suggesting that {it}lay{/it} is on the rise socially. But if it does rise to respectability, it is sure to do so slowly: many people have invested effort in learning to keep {it}lie{/it} and {it}lay{/it} distinct. Remember that even though many people do use {it}lay{/it} for {it}lie{/it}, others will judge you unfavorably if you do.

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}licgan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}ligen{/it} to lie, Latin {it}lectus{/it} bed, Greek {it}lechos{/it}
shortdef: to be or to stay at rest in a horizontal position : be prostrate : rest, recline
to assume a horizontal position —often used with down
to reside temporarily : stay for the night : lodge

dt: {bc}the position or situation in which something lies {dx_def}see {dxt|lie:1||}{/dx_def}

dt.t: a golf ball in a difficult {wi}lie{/wi}

dt: {bc}the {d_link|haunt|haunt:2} of an animal (such as a fish) {bc}{sx|covert||}
{bc}an act or instance of lying or resting

shortdef: the position or situation in which something lies
the haunt of an animal (such as a fish) : covert

dt: {bc}to make an untrue statement with {d_link|intent|intent:1} to deceive

dt.t: She was {wi}lying{/wi} when she said she didn't break the vase.
He {wi}lied{/wi} about his past experience.

dt: {bc}to create a false or misleading impression

dt.t: Statistics sometimes {wi}lie{/wi}.
The mirror never {wi}lies{/wi}.
He {it}lied{/it} his way out of trouble.

pt: {sc}lie{/sc} {sc}prevaricate{/sc} {sc}equivocate{/sc} {sc}palter{/sc} {sc}fib{/sc} mean to tell an untruth. {sc}lie{/sc} is the blunt term, imputing dishonesty.
{sc}prevaricate{/sc} softens the bluntness of {sc}lie{/sc} by implying quibbling or confusing the issue.

pt.t: during the hearings the witness did his best to {it}prevaricate{/it}

pt: {sc}equivocate{/sc} implies using words having more than one sense so as to seem to say one thing but intend another.

pt.t: {it}equivocated{/it} endlessly in an attempt to mislead her inquisitors

pt: {sc}palter{/sc} implies making unreliable statements of fact or intention or insincere promises.
{sc}fib{/sc} applies to a telling of a trivial untruth.

pt.t: {it}fibbed{/it} about the price of the new suit

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}lēogan{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}liogan{/it} to lie, Old Church Slavonic {it}lŭgati{/it}
shortdef: to make an untrue statement with intent to deceive
to create a false or misleading impression
to bring about by telling lies

dt: {bc}an assertion of something known or believed by the speaker or writer to be untrue with {d_link|intent|intent:1} to deceive

dt.t: He told a {wi}lie{/wi} to avoid punishment.

dt: {bc}an untrue or inaccurate statement that may or may not be believed true by the speaker or writer

dt.t: the {wi}lies{/wi} we tell ourselves to feel better
historical records containing numerous {wi}lies{/wi}
His show of remorse was a {wi}lie{/wi}.

et: Middle English {it}lige, lie{/it}, from Old English {it}lyge{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}lugī{/it}, Old English {it}lēogan{/it} to lie
shortdef: an assertion of something known or believed by the speaker or writer to be untrue with intent to deceive
an untrue or inaccurate statement that may or may not be believed true by the speaker or writer

dt.t: The information he gave us was just {it}a pack of lies{/it}.
Let's see {it}how the land lies{/it} before we make any decisions.

shortdef: the true facts about a situation

dt: used to say that a statement, fact, or detail expresses the substance of something

dt.t: They have to make a decision soon. {it}Therein lies{/it} the problem. If they act too quickly, they run the risk of choosing the wrong plan.

shortdef: —used to say that a statement, fact, or detail expresses the substance of something

dt.t: I don't know what to do, and {it}therein lies the problem{/it}.

dt: {bc}a story or report that is completely false {bc}a story that is full of lies

dt.t: The article was nothing but {it}a tissue of lies{/it}.
He has {phrase}woven a tissue of lies{/phrase} about his military record.

shortdef: a story or report that is completely false : a story that is full of lies

dt: {bc}a deliberate gross distortion of the truth used especially as a propaganda tactic

shortdef: a deliberate gross distortion of the truth used especially as a propaganda tactic
